head.title: Academy in Shrub Oak Is Now on the Market

hedline.hl1: Academy in Shrub Oak Is Now on the Market

abstract.p: Phoenix Academy, substance abuse rehabilitation program for teens, puts up for sale, at $15 million, 140-acre campus in Shrub Oak, NY, that includes five-story, 270,000-square foot building, six houses and several outbuildings; photo (M)

block.p: A 140-ACRE property atop a hill with views of parkland has gone on the market for $15 million. It is currently the Shrub Oak campus of Phoenix Academy, a substance abuse rehabilitation program for teenagers.

The campus includes a five-story, 270,000-square-foot building, six houses used for staff residences and several other outbuildings. The main building, which houses dormitories, classrooms, offices and a bomb shelter, sits on a lawn surrounded by a stone wall in northern Westchester.

A 140-ACRE property atop a hill with views of parkland has gone on the market for $15 million. It is currently the Shrub Oak campus of Phoenix Academy, a substance abuse rehabilitation program for teenagers.

The campus includes a five-story, 270,000-square-foot building, six houses used for staff residences and several other outbuildings. The main building, which houses dormitories, classrooms, offices and a bomb shelter, sits on a lawn surrounded by a stone wall in northern Westchester.

''Finding this kind of property in Westchester is very, very rare,'' said Andrew J. Gerringer, senior vice president of Douglas Elliman, the company in Manhattan that, with Sally Siano & Associates in Bedford Hills, is handling the sale. He added that Phoenix House, which bought the property for $3 million at an auction in 1983, wants to take advantage of the strong real estate market.
The campus was built in 1954 as the site of Loyola Seminary, which was owned by the Jesuits. The property was later sold to a Bible college.
The current sale has attracted not only academic institutions but also developers of corporate retreats, golf courses, health clubs, assisted living housing and homes.
Houses in a nearby subdivision on Stony Street are selling for $700,000.

''The amount of people who are interested in this property is just staggering; it's huge,'' said Steve Siano, the listing Bedford Hills real estate agent. ''I didn't even know there were this many developers.

''Every day I get calls from them, not just from around here, but from New Jersey, Long Island, Queens -- one guy flew up from Florida. Some developers say they want to use the building; others want to knock it down. I've heard it all, except I'm waiting for heliports and polo fields.''

Phoenix Academy currently has 50 staffers and about 250 students, ranging in age from 14 to 18. ''We, like other not-for-profits, have to constantly review the value of our assets to see if we can improve or expand our services,'' said Peter Kerr, a spokesman for Phoenix House.

When Phoenix Academy first came to Shrub Oak, there was considerable antagonism toward the drug rehabilitation center. But the opposition subsided over time, and Phoenix House has been ''almost a silent neighbor,'' said Linda G. Cooper, the town supervisor of Yorktown, which includes Shrub Oak.

''We would hope to have another similarly quiet institution,'' Ms. Cooper said. ''This is a very important piece of Yorktown. It is visible from the skyline all over. It's in the Lakeland School District. It's in a residential area, and it's surrounded by an awful lot of parkland.''

Like many Northern Westchester districts, Lakeland is having problems with school crowding, and Ms. Cooper said she feared a residential development would overburden the schools. She added that Yorktown already had several facilities to house the elderly, including senior housing, assisted living and a residence for patients with Alzheimer's disease.
